This study deals with the development and evaluation of lanthana promoted Cu-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The samples were prepared using solution combustion synthesis method. The study demonstrates that the incorporation of 3wt% lanthana (La2O3) into a CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 results in a catalyst with exceptionally high catalytic performance. The synthesized catalysts were thoroughly characterized by various analytical tools such as HRTEM, XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, H2-TPD and CO2-TPD. The catalysts were assessed for CO2 hydrogenation reaction in a high-pressure fixed-bed reactor. The La2O3 promoted catalyst with a composition of 0.6Cu/0.3ZnO/0.03La2O3/0.07Al2O3 was selective to methanol (60%) even at an operating temperature as high as 325 °C and an operating pressure of 85 bars. Under similar operating conditions, the 0.6Cu/0.3ZnO/0.03La2O3/0.07Al2O3 catalyst exhibited better CO2 conversion, MeOH selectivity and MeOH production as compared to unpromoted catalyst, 0.6Cu/0.3ZnO/0.1Al2O3. At reaction conditions of T = 300 °C, P = 85 bar, and GHSV=55,000h-1, the lanthana promoted catalyst showed a CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity of 20% and 65%, respectively; while the production rates of carbon monoxide and methanol were 0.55 g/g-cat h−1 and 0.79 g/g-cat h−1. The high catalytic efficiency is attributed to the formation of oxygen vacancies and/or generation of defects in the catalyst surface, smaller Cu nanoparticles with LaOx, and a comparable larger number of mild basic sites. Similar catalyst prepared by wet impregnation method performed poorly, thus highlighting the role of combustion synthesis and the effect of temperature in forming unique metal oxide phases responsible for higher catalytic performance. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lanthana promotion Cu-nanocatalyst Methanol synthesis Solution combustion synthesis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Global warming caused by the emission of greenhouse gasses (GHGS) has attracted much attention recently [1]. Carbon dioxide (CO2) is the primary GHGS, and its high emissions from a wide range of sources account for around 60% of the global warming [2]. In light of the fact that anthropogenic CO2 emissions are still rising, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) recommends that they be handled sustainably and responsibly [3]. Thus, with the aim to contain these emissions, Global CO2 Initiative (GCI), proposed reduction in CO2 emissions by its capture and conversion into value added products [3–6]. Among products, the catalytic conversion of CO2 into methanol has a great potential for CO2 utilization [7]. This is because the CO2 hydrogenation process can be used to generate large amounts of methanol, which can then be utilized as a fuel or transformed into a variety of other fine chemicals [8]. As can be seen in Table 1 , several noble and non-noble metal-based catalysts have been researched for the catalytic conversion of CO2 into methanol. Among these, it has been observed that catalysts based on palladium (Pd), platinum (Pt), gold (Au), indium (In), and copper (Cu) demonstrate relatively better activity, selectivity, and stability [9–16]. Nonetheless, copper-based catalysts are the preferable option due to their desirable activity, low cost, ease of availability, and commercial applicability. Recently, there has been a lot of interest in copper-based ternary catalysts made of copper oxide, zinc oxide, and alumina (CZA) since they are commercially applicable [12,17–20]. The main challenges with Cu catalysts are the deactivation of the catalysts caused on by phase transformation and side reactions like the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS), especially at operating temperatures of ≥300 °C. Due to its diverse structural makeup and low hydrophilicity, zirconia (ZrO2) based catalysts have also been proposed as a suitable carrier for copper-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. As a result, the development of catalysts supported on zirconia is currently receiving a lot of interest and copper-based catalysts supported on either Zirconia (ZrO2) or mixed oxide of zirconia has proven to improve the stability and activity of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts [21–24]. It has been observed that the synergistic effects of two active sites, namely intermetallic Cu-ZrOx complexes and oxygen vacancies at the interference of Cu-ZrOx, lead to the development of more effective catalysts [23,25,26]. For example, K. Sun and co-workers reported on extremely effective catalysts supported by mixed indium and zirconia oxides. About 0.6 gMeOH/g-Cat.h can be produced with this catalyst at working temperatures of T = 475 K, P = 50 bars, and GHSV=21000h−1. The oxygen vacancies induced by ZrO2 incorporation were responsible for the improved catalytic activity [27]. Similar to this, the exceptional catalytic activity of ZrO2 supported catalysts was linked to the strong metal support interaction (SMSI) effects between Cu and ZrO2. The ZrO2 supported catalyst demonstrated higher CO2 conversion, as well as a higher methanol yield of around 0.07 gMeOH/g-Cat.h at reaction conditions of T = 260 °C, P = 30 bars, and GHSV of 2400 h−1 [25]. In one noteworthy investigation, Pd was incorporated into the ZnZrOX solid solution catalyst, which led to enhanced methanol yield and stability over a 100 h test period in comparison to the unpromoted catalyst. It was reported that, palladium can scatter atomically over ZnZrOX up to 0.6 wt percent, which enhances the number of surface vacancies. Under operating conditions of P = 50 bars, T = 320 °C, GHSV=24,000 h−1, and an H2/CO2 ratio of 4, the Pd-ZnZrOX catalyst demonstrated exceptionally high CO2 conversion (15%) and high MeOH yield of about 0.7 gMeOH/g-cat.h [28]. Several studies employing ZrO2 as support for copper-based CO2 hydrogenation catalysts have shown similar results [29–31]. It has also been claimed that the addition of promoters can improve the activity and stability. For instance, the activity of CZA catalysts was reported to improve with the incorporation of La2O3, a rare earth metal oxide. It has been suggested that there is a hydrogen spill over at the interference of Cu-ZrO2 and Cu-La2O3 responsible for higher activity [32–34]. Numerous studies have shown the existence of dual-site and/or bi-functional catalysts, in which CO2 molecules are adsorbed on the ZrO2 or La2O3 sites while hydrogen is chemisorbed dissociated on the Cu active sites. The adsorbed carbon species on the Cu surface are then hydrogenated to produce methanol when atomic hydrogen spills over onto the surface of ZrO2/La2O3. This information allows one to draw the conclusion that the very high catalytic efficiency is thought to be caused by the generation of surface defects, smaller Cu nanoparticles in close association with LaOx, and a comparable larger number of mild basic sites [34–37]. La2O3 also exhibits strong basicity, making it an intriguing option for the active phase in processes utilizing solid bases. It has been reported that the nature of the basic sites on the catalyst surface accelerates the turnover rates of methanol [34,38]. There are reports on incorporation of La-oxide into Cu-catalysts resulting in increased conversion and selectivity; however, there are contracting reports as well where effects of La had a negative impact especially in activity of Cu-catalyst [42]. Moreover, the CO2 hydrogenation catalysts preparative methodology has also been recognized as a crucial component of catalyst development that influences the overall effectiveness of the catalysts [39–42]. Because to their many advantages, the aqueous wetness impregnation and deposition precipitation synthesis procedures are the most popular and frequently used methods for producing industrial and laboratory scale catalysts [43–45]. However, the relationship between the synthesis process and catalytic performance has been the subject of numerous studies and debates about the best method for synthesizing CO2 hydrogenation catalysts still exist. For instance, one of the reports compared wetness impregnation, precipitation deposition, and citric acid impregnation. The catalysts prepared using the citric acid method showed greater activity for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, which led to an improvement in the production of methanol of about >130% [39]. Recently, among synthesis techniques, the solution combustion synthesis (SCS) method has experienced a notable rise in popularity. This is because the mass production of high-quality nanomaterials and nanocomposites has attracted interest for a number of applications, with the synthesis of catalytic materials at its center [46–49]. Previously, we have successfully used the SCS technique to develop highly active and stable nanocatalysts for a variety of applications [50–53]. Thus, considering the significance of the SCS technique in the catalyst design for Cu-based catalysts, the current work was also dedicated to explore on the lanthana incorporation into the copper-based catalysts using the SCS technique. From the above, it is clear that researchers continue to face a significant task and challenge in designing efficient CO2 hydrogenation catalysts. According to the literature, the development of a promising catalyst for methanol synthesis depends on the synthesis technique of catalyst synthesis, the choice of active components, and the presence of a suitable promoter. The current effort aims to develop copper-based nanocatalysts for the hydrogenation of CO2 into methanol that is active, selective, and stable. For this purpose, the technique of SCS is used and lanthanum oxide is introduced as a promoter in the CZA composition. A Cu/Zn/Al-based catalyst's synthesis, characterization, and catalytic evaluation, as well as lanthanum doping, are part of the study presented in this publication. A catalyst with a comparable composition was also prepared using the traditional impregnation technique. In addition to comparing the impacts of various catalysts on CO2 hydrogenation, the study also examines how lanthana promotes methanol selectivity and yield. 2 Experimental procedures 2.1 Preparation of the catalysts The following catalysts were prepared using solution combustion synthesis (SCS) method: 30wt%CuO/49.65wt%ZnO/20.35wt%Al2O3, 60wt%CuO-30wt%ZnO10wt%Al2O3, and 60wt%CuO-27wt%ZnO/3wt%La2O3/10wt%Al2O3. These catalysts were labelled as C1, C2, and C2L, respectively. In our previously published papers, the SCS procedure is discussed in details [50,53]. For instance, to prepare the C1 catalyst, 9.1 g of copper nitrate hexahydrate (Cu(NO3)2·6H2O, BDH 98.5%%), 18.15 g of zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, Sigma Aldrich 98%), and 14.12 g of aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O, Sigma Aldrich, 99%), were dissolved in deionized water in a 500 mL beaker. Moreover, 4.8 g of glycine (Sigma Aldrich, 98.5%) were added in line with the glycine to nitrates ratio of 1.3. The resulting uniform mixture was thoroughly agitated for an hour before being heated for combustion. A soft gel formed from the fluid before a self-sustaining combustion reaction started. The post-combustion powder was heated to 600 °C in air at a rate of 1 °C/min and calcined for three hours. The C2L catalyst's activity was benchmarked with the C2L-I catalyst, which had a comparable composition and was synthesized using an impregnation method described in the literature [54]. Concisely, during this process, five grams of alumina (Sigma Aldrich, >99.9%) was degassed at 150 °C, and then the aforementioned amounts of precursor salts were dissolved in deionized water appropriate to the pore volume and added dropwise to the degassed support with constant stirring. The resulting slurry was dried for eight hours at 120 °C.The aforementioned conditions were likewise used for the calcination of the C1L-I catalyst. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts The catalysts' bulk phase and crystal structure were examined using the analytical method of X-ray diffraction (XRD). X-ray diffractometer measurements were made on the samples using a benchtop model (Rigaku, MiniFlexII). A high-resolution electron microscope (JEOL, 2010) with an operating voltage of around 200 kV was used to assess the catalysts' morphology. To prepare samples for analysis, they were sonicated in n-propanol to scatter them. Then, a drop of the evenly dispersed mixture was put on a copper grid with a 250 mesh size. The chemical make-up and oxidation states of the different species on the surface were examined using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (AXIS Ultra DLD, KRATOS). Analyses of calcined samples by the analytic method of temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were carried out using ChemiSorb2750 (Micromeritics). The quartz tube was loaded with about 200 mg of the sample, which was degassed at 200 °C for two hours at a flow rate of 30 ml/min of pure Ar. After that, the temperature was lowered to 40 °C, and the flow was changed to 30 cm3min−1 of 10vol%H2 in argon (Ar). By increasing furnace temperature from 40 °C to 900 °C at a heating rate of 5 °Cmin-1, the TPR thermogram was recorded. The nature and kinds of active sites for H2 and CO2 were examined using the analytical method of temperature programmed desorption (TPD). In a self-built system, analysis of CO2-TPD and H2-TPD was performed. A quartz reactor and an automated electric furnace make up this system. A quadrupole mass spectrometer was linked online to this system (Hiden analytical, HPR20). In this process, the sample was initially activated by reduction for two hours at 350 °C in a flow of 30 SCCM of a mixture of 10vol%H2/N2. After that, the furnace temperature was cooled to ambient temperature and then purged in 30 SCCM of pure He for 30 min. The catalysts were then saturated with CO2 or H2 for two hours at 50 °C. The samples were purged again in He flow to get rid of the physisorbed gasses. TPD measurements were then recorded by increasing furnace temperature from 50 °C to 900 °C at 2 °C/min increment. 2.3 Catalytic activity study A high-pressure lab-scale unit (Effi, PID, Micromeritics) was used to examine the efficiency of the catalysts in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The equipment has three gas lines controlled by highly accurate mass flow controllers, and a fixed bed reactor built of hastelloy with an internal diameter of 9.3 mm. A three-zone electric furnace heats the reactor tube. The exit stream of the reactor was cooled by employing a paltrier cold trap, which divides liquid and gaseous products. Temperature readings of the reaction were taken using a thermocouple that was positioned inside the catalytic bed. The gaseous products were evaluated using an online GC-TCD whereas, the liquid products were separated in a trap at 5 °C, and were analyzed using an offline GC-FID (Agilent 7890A). In order to carry out the test, 0.5 g of the sample was palletized, sieved to a mesh size of 75–150 μm, and physically mixed with around one g of quartz powder of a comparable size. By sandwiching it between two layers of quartz wool, this sample was placed into the vertical reactor. The catalyst was subsequently activated by reducing it for three hours at atmospheric pressure at 500 °C in 30 SCCM of pure hydrogen. After the temperature was reduced to 250 °C, the flow was swiched to a mixture of the reactants with a flowrate of 3.87 NL/h and a composition of H2/CO2/N2 (45vol%/15vol%/5vol%), resulting in a GHSV of 7000 h−1. The reaction was then recorded after increasing the reactor's pressure to 60 bars. Fig. 1a illustrates the apparent diffraction peaks of CuO and ZnO for the C1 catalyst [55–58]. The strength of distinct CuO diffraction peaks gradually decreased as CuO loading increased, but the line width only slightly widened, suggesting that the increase in CuO loading either enhanced the dispersion of the CuO species or increased mixed oxides and surface defects. Furthermore, the major diffraction lines were unaffected by the 3wt% lanthana addition. It is important to note that the intensities of primary CuO peaks dropped, particularly the diffraction peak at 2-theta value of 39°, which denoted a reduction in the size of the metal oxide particles. Fig. 1A(d) shows that the XRD spectrum of the C2L-I catalyst had distinct diffraction patterns than the C2L-SCS catalyst. The C2L-I catalyst's diffraction lines were sharper and more intense compared to those of the C2L-SCS catalyst, which suggests that the metal particle sizes were larger. This characteristic was related to the combustion process during synthesis, in which the catalyst is exposed to high temperatures and produces distinct phases that are different from those produced by the traditional impregnation approach. During the combustion process, there is also a considerable evolution of gasses (carbon oxides, water vapor, nitrogen oxides), so the samples synthesized by the combustion method have a high porosity and surface area compared to the conventional methods of catalyst preparation. Fig. 1B shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts after an ex-situ reduction at a temperature of 500 °C. As can be observed, activation of the samples through reduction causes the XRD patterns to change resulting in the appearance of new diffraction lines, with the relative strongest diffraction line located at a 2θ value of about 43° [59], demonstrating that for all activated samples, bulk crystalline copper exists in the form of zerovalent copper phase. The C1 catalyst's considerably broader diffraction peak indicates that the metallic copper crystallite size was the smallest of the catalysts, which is interesting. Moreover, for the C2L-I catalysts the diffraction lines corresponding to Cuo was the sharpest and most intense, indicating that the metallic copper crystallites were larger. 3.2 Catalysts morphology The morphology in terms of the size and distribution of the metal oxide particles were examined using HRTEM; the results are shown in Fig. 2 . The metal oxide nanoparticles of the C1 catalyst were uniformly dispersed over the alumina substrate and had a constant size, as can be seen. In contrast to the C1 catalyst, the C2 catalyst had larger metal particles. Additionally, compared to the C1 catalyst, this catalyst showed a wider distribution of metal particles. For the C1 and C2 catalysts, the average size of the metal oxide particles was 5.2 ± 1.1 and 15.1 ± 3.8, respectively. Similar trend has been described in the literature [57,60,61]. It is interesting to note that the C2 catalyst's average metal oxide particle size decreased with the addition of lanthana; the average metal oxide particle size for the promoted C2L catalyst was 13.3 ± 3.2 nm. The results of the TEM analysis and the XRD analysis agreed with each other. 3.3 Surface chemical composition of the catalysts The surface chemical composition of the catalysts was investigated using the analytical method of X-ray photoelectron (XPS) measurement and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . As can be seen in Fig. 3A, the Cu2p peaks in the XPS spectra of the SCS-prepared C1, C2, and C2L catalysts were noticeably wider and less symmetrical, indicating increased variability in their copper chemical environment. For example, the Cu2p peak of the 30wt%CuO (C1) catalyst consisted of three peaks. Cu2p3/2 peaks with binding energies of 933.2 eV and 934.6 eV, respectively, were presumably originated by weakly associated aCu2+ species and strongly associated bCu2+ species [62–64]. Furthermore, the third Cu2p3/2 peak, appearing at 936.08 eV, was attributed to cCu2+ species that were presumably induced into the lattices of Al2O3 and/or La2O3 and thus producing surface defects and oxygen vacancies. The proportions of aCu2+, bCu2+, and cCu2+ ions were, respectively, 42%, 36%, and 21.6%. The proportion of strongly ionized cCu2+ ions in the C2 catalyst increased to 36.47% even though the Cu species present in the XPS spectra of the C2 catalyst were equivalent to those present in the C1 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 3A (b). It is important to stress that for the promoted catalyst, a change in binding energies to higher values was recorded. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 3A (c), the major copper species were highly ionized and induced copper ions (bCu2+ and cCu2+) while aCu2+ species contributed around 12% only. The amount of strongly ionized cCu2+ ions in this catalyst was likewise the highest, at roughly 51%. This behavior was attributed to the C2 catalyst's increased surface defects and oxygen vacancies caused by the insertion of 3wt% lanthana. A similar behavior has been reported by Chen and co-workers [65]. According to their findings, adding lanthana to a copper catalyst supported by mesoporous silica caused the creation of more Cu-LaOx interferences. These interferences were said to be the cause of the catalysts' excellent catalytic activity [65]. The CO2 hydrogenation reaction confirmed the C2L catalyst's comparatively higher catalytic performance, as will be covered in more detail in a later section. The C2L-I catalyst (produced using a traditional approach) had a Cu2p spectrum that, in contrast to the catalysts made using SCS, showed that Cu was mostly present in the chemical state of CuO with binding energies of 931.6 eV, 932.54 eV, and 934.5 eV. It is worth to mention that this catalyst also exhibited presence of around 12% of metallic copper species whereas the SCS catalysts did not indicate presence of metallic copper species. Three Cu2p peaks were identified in the deconvoluted XPS spectrum of the C2L-I catalyst: the binding energies at 931.6 eV and 932.54 eV were attributed to the presence of metallic copper, a loosely associated aCu2+ species, and the binding energies at 934.50 eV were attributed to bCu2+ species interacting with the support. In contrast to SCS catalysts, the C2L-I catalyst revealed no development of induced phases, indicating less interaction between Cu and La. Fig. 3B (d) shows representative core-level Zn2p spectra for the C2L-I catalyst. The Zn2p3/2 was deconvoluted into two peaks, as can be seen, suggesting the presence of two species that correspond to Zn2+. While the shoulder-appearing binding energy of 1022.3 eV may have originated from metal support contact, the peak at binding energy of 1021.1 eV was linked to the existence of bulk divalent zinc molecules. A change to a higher binding energy of Zn2p was observed for the SCS-prepared C1, C2, and C2L catalysts and thus indicating a close interaction between copper and zinc. The C2L catalyst showed the most notable modification, with the Zn2p being significantly wider and more shifted to higher binding energy. The observed La3d5/2 and La3d3/2 of the C2L-I catalysts appeared at binding energies of 835 eV and 850 eV, respectively, as shown in Fig. 3C(a), which was typical of the existence of La2O3 species [66]. The La3d spectra of the C2L catalyst were comparably broader and occurred at higher binging energies than that of the C2L-I catalyst. Confirming the diversity in the chemical environment and the numerous interactions of LaOx with copper oxide. According to Fig. 4 , for the C1, C2, and C2L catalysts, there is a proportional increase in the highly ionized cCu2+ ions upon increasing the CuO loading to 60% and upon adding 3% lanthanum oxide to the C2 catalyst. This is clearly shown in their linear relationship, which predicts the formation of non-stoichiometric phases between Cu and La2O3/Al2O3, which are linked to the formation of induced phases. Therefore, it makes sense to hypothesize that during the SCS, Cu is inserted into the La2O3 and/or Al2O3 lattice, creating an oxygen vacancy and a non-stoichiometric solid solution. 3.4 Reducibility of the catalysts The H2-TPR analysis is an important analytical tool to reveal various metal-metal and metal-support interactions. The results are shown in Fig. 5 . The thermograms demonstrate that all three catalysts—C1, C2 and C2L—prepared using the SCS method contained two reduction peaks—a low temperature peak in the range of 150 °C to 400 °C and a high temperature peak (>370 °C). These peaks were further deconvoluted indicating multiple stages of reduction of and thus presence of various reductive species. For instance, the thermogram of the C1 catalyst corresponded to a combination of two Cu species, as illustrated in Fig. 5a. Lower temperature reduction peak was defined as the first reduction peak with maximum at 235 °C. This reduction peak was divided into four peaks, each with a maximum temperature of 174 °C, 200 °C, 233 °C, and 261 °C, respectively. This lower reduction peak is most likely caused by the presence of loosely interacting CuO species. The second reduction peak, also referred to as the high temperature peak, had two peaks with maximum temperatures of 471 °C and 614 °C, respectively, and was substantially wider. These peaks could be attributed to the decrease of Cu2+ species that have been induced into the alumina matrix or Cu2+ species that are experiencing significant metal support interaction. The C2 catalyst had a reduction pattern resembling that of the C1 catalyst. The reduction peaks for the C2 catalyst were, however, located at a temperature that was approximately 100 °C higher than that of the C1 catalyst. The lower decrease peak, for instance, was deconvoluted into three peaks with maxima at 240 °C, 308 °C, and 350 °C, as shown in Fig. 5b. Moreover, the high temperature reduction peak was integrated into three peaks with maxima at 560 °C, 662 °C and 740 °C, respectively. These were also higher than that of the reduction temperature of C1 catalyst. The C2L catalyst showed a reduction pattern that was identical to the C2 catalyst, although the reduction temperatures were ∼10 °Clower. The reduction behavior of the C2L-I (produced by precipitation method) catalyst was significantly different from that of the catalysts prepared by the SCS method. As demonstrated in Fig. 5d, the TPR analysis revealed that the C2L-I catalyst (with similar composition to that of the C2L) mainly consisted of weakly interacting CuO species only. This is because no high temperature reduction peak was recorded in the thermogram of the C2L-I catalyst prepared by conventional method. H2-TPR study actually corroborated the XPS analysis results, which showed that the SCS preparation process resulted in the formation of induced copper species into the alumina and/or lanthana crystal lattice. 3.5 Temperature program desorption (TPD) studies of the catalysts Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) techniques were used to study the characteristics of the H2 and CO2 active sites. H2-TPD analysis was carried out for the pre-reduced catalysts to better understand the hydrogen adsorption capabilities of the catalysts. All catalysts had two hydrogen desorption peaks, as seen in Fig. 6 , demonstrating the existence of two distinct hydrogen surface adsorption modes. In contrast, the appearance of a broader peak in the temperature range between 250 °C and 450 °C can be attributed to the desorption of atomic H2 at active sites. The desorption peak in the temperature range from 450 °C to 750 °C is presumably caused by the desorption of securely attached hydrogen [67]. It is important to note that the addition of lanthanum to the C2 catalyst caused the desorption peaks to shift to lower temperatures, indicating that the lanthanum favored hydrogen desorption. This phenomenon was possibly brought on by an increase in surface defects and metal oxide dispersion. The easier adsorption of hydrogen species on the surface and desorption at relatively lower temperatures were presumably caused by the increase in dispersion, the smaller size of the metal oxide particles, the surface defects, and the oxygen vacancies. This pattern is consistent with earlier literature reports [67,68]. Fig. 7 illustrates the findings from the CO2-TPD study on the nature and existence of basic surface sites. The desorption profile of the C1 catalyst is characterized by the existence of two peaks. Low temperature desorption (LT), which takes place between 100 °C and 300 °C, has been linked to weak basic sites. Strong basic sites have been suggested to be responsible for the second, more intense and widespread desorption peak, known as high temperature desorption (HT), which occurred in the high temperature range between 500 °C and 800 °C. The C2 catalyst was also characterized by the presence of the CO2 desorption peaks HT and HT. An additional peak was also recorded in the temperature range between 400 °C and 600 °C. The existence of moderate basic surface sites have been linked to the existence of this peak. It is worth noting that the C2L catalyst promoted by Lanthana exhibited different CO2 desorption behavior. First, the intensity of the desorption peaks LT and HT decreased. The formation of surface defects as a result of the interaction of LaOx and copper species, which resulted in the formation of new active sites for CO2 adsorption, was attributed to the occurrence of a second, wider CO2 desorption peak in the temperature range between 300 °C and 600 °C with a maximum at about 450 °C. This shows that the addition of lanthanum to the C2 catalyst enhanced the moderately basic sites while decreasing the weakly basic and strongly basic sites. 3.6 Effects of catalyst composition on the catalytic performances The primary products of the CO2 hydrogenation reaction were methanol, water, carbon monoxide, and methane. Moreover, there were also traces of ethanol and propanol found at reaction temperatures >250 °C. The conversion of CO2 over the C2 catalyst was obviously considerably higher than the C1 catalyst, as shown in Fig. 8 a. For the C2 catalyst, at reaction conditions of T = 275 °C, P = 85b, and GHSV= 7,700h−1, a high conversion of CO2 conversion of about 27% was achieved. These results indicated that increasing CuO loading from 30wt% to 60wt% significantly improved the catalytic activity. Compared to the C1 catalyst, MeOH selectivity over the C2 catalyst was lower. It is worth mentioning that at a reaction conditions of T = 275 °C and GHSV=7,700h−1, the difference in MeOH selectivity's for C1 and C2 was smaller as compared to other reaction conditions. The selectivities of the products were significantly impacted by the reaction temperature. MeOH selectivity dropped for both catalysts as reaction temperature rose from 250 °C to 275 °C, although CO selectivity increased at the same time. For example, at 250 °C the selectivity of MeOH over the C1 and C2 catalysts was 80%, and 61.3%, respectively, which decreased to 62%, and 45% at 275 °C, respectively. The relationship between the rise in CO selectivity and the fall in MeOH selectivity with increasing operating temperature may be due to increased reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction activity. Due to its endothermic nature, RWGS is thermodynamically beneficial with an increase in reaction temperature [69–71]. However, as can be seen in Fig. 8b, increasing the CuO content of the C2 catalyst to 60wt% also led to an increase in the formation of undesirable CH4. For instance, methane selectivity over the C1 catalyst was minimal (0.7%) at 275 °C, but it increased to 2.3% when the same reaction conditions were used with the C2 catalyst. Fig. 8c demonstrates also that the C2 catalyst produced methanol at a faster rate than the C1 catalyst. It is also crucial to note that the C2 catalyst's relatively better performance was likely caused by the synergistic effects of the CuO and ZnO phases. This behavior was in accordance with the published literature, where increase in copper loading resulted in catalysts with comparatively higher catalytic performances during CO2 hydrogenation reaction to methanol. According to some theories, increasing copper loading can result in the development of additional active sites, which improves catalytic activity. For instance, according to Karelovic and Ruiz, copper-based catalysts with a loading of ≥8wt% demonstrated stronger catalytic activity than catalysts with lower copper loadings [72]. Similar to this, Israfuddin et al. reported on the effect of copper loading in the range of 5wt% to 25wt% on the catalytic performance of Cu-ZrO2 supported carbon nanofibers (CNFs) catalysts in liquid phase CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. According to reports, the 15 wt percent Cu catalyst had the highest level of activity, producing 20 g/kg.cat.h of methanol [73]. 3.7 Effects of La2O3 incorporation on the catalytic performances According to Fig. 9 a, the maximum CO2 conversion for the promoted (C2L) catalyst was achieved at 275 °C as compared to 20% for the unpromoted (C2) catalyst under analogous conditions. This demonstrates that adding lanthana significantly increased the CO2 conversion. Moreover, selectivity of MeOH over La promoted catalyst was higher than the unpromoted catalyst in reaction temperature <275 °C and at GHSV of 7,700h−1. It is important to mention that with further increase in reaction temperature, both promoted and unpromoted catalysts exhibited nearly similar products distribution. Increasing the pressure, reaction temperature and other variables exhibited the aforementioned trends. The drop in methanol selectivity with rise in reaction temperature was less pronounced with the lanthana promoted C2L catalyst. MeOH selectivity over C2L decreased from 65% to 60% when the reaction temperature was increased from 250 °C to 275 °C, whilst MeOH selectivity of the unpromoted C2 catalyst declined from 60% to 45% (Fig. 9b). Due to enhanced CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity, lanthana-promoted catalyst displayed increased space-time yield (STY) of MeOH (Fig. 9d). The best activity of the lanthana promoted catalyst obtained was at a CO2 conversion of ∼20%, and with yield of MeOH and CO yield of 0.45 g/g-cat h−1 and 0.47 g/g-cat h−1, respectively (reaction conditions were TR=300 °C, PR=85b, GHSV=19,000h−1 and H2/CO2=4). A comparison of the lanthanum promoted catalysts of this study with earlier closely reported literature is given in Table 1. As can be seen, the yields for lanthana promoted Cu-based catalysts are comparable to some of the high methanol yielding catalysts. Positive impact of lanthana is in accordance with the earlier reported work. For instance, Guo and colleagues created a number of lanthana-promoted Cu-based catalysts supported on ZrO2 and discovered that adding lanthana to the Cu/ZrO2 increased the basic sites and caused the Cu active sites to disperse, which in turn increased MeOH selectivity and CO2 conversion [34]. Similar to this, Zhang et al. stated that the Lanthana modified CuO-ZnO-ZrO2/HZSM-5 catalyst's comparative superior catalytic performance was caused by an increase in Cu dispersion and an increase in the Cu+/Cu ratio due to the induction of the Lanthana [74]. Other research teams have achieved similar outcomes of modifying Cu-based catalysts with lanthana for a variety of catalytic applications [75–79]. There are a number of differences between the C2L nanocatalyst and the unpromoted C2 catalyst that account for the exceptionally high activity and selectivity of the former: (a) the surface defects and oxygen vacancies found in the C2L nanocatalyst were confirmed by the results of the XPS and H2-TPR analyses. Because Cu was primarily distributed in the form of CuO and there was no evidence of surface defects or oxygen vacancies, the C2L-I catalyst therefore, was less active; (b) According to the XRD study, the C2L nanocatalyst had smaller metal oxide particle sizes than C2L; this suggests that C2L's performance advantage over C2L is likely the result of this. The C2L-SCS and C2L-I have respective average metal particle sizes of 17.23 nm and 23.61 nm (calculated using Debye Scherer's equation); (c) As demonstrated by CO2-TPD data, the increased activity may possibly be attributed to the abundance of moderate basic sites.; and (d) High spillover of hydrogen over the C2-L catalyst as was revealed by H2TPD results. Incorporation of lantana lowered the temperature of hydrogen desorption presumably due to high hydrogen spill over. However, despite superior activity for CO2 hydrogenation, higher MeOH selectivity and yield than that of the unpromoted C2 catalyst, selectivity to CH4 over the C2L catalyst was also comparatively higher. As can be seen in Fig. 9c, CH4 selectivity rose as reaction temperature increased, reaching a maximum of 4.3% at 275 °C and 15,000h−1 in space. With the unpromoted C2 catalyst, the decrease in CH4 generation with an increase in GHSV from 15,000 h−1 and 19,000 h−1, respectively, was not significant. 3.8 Effects of space velocities on activity It is evident from the literature that hourly gas space velocities have profound effects on the activity of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts [89–92]. In general, increasing the space velocity was reported to increase methanol selectivity, methanol yield, and methanol production rate. On the other hand, as space velocity increased, CO selectivity, CO yield, and percent CO2 turnover all decreased [89–92]. The aforementioned results served as inspiration for additional research that was done to examine the impact of high space velocities (27,000h−1 to 55,000h−1) on the efficiency of the promoted C2L catalyst during the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Fig. 10 illustrates how a rise in space velocity led to a drop in the percentage of CO2 being converted. For example, at a reaction temperature of 275 °C and an increase in space velocity from 7,700h−1 to 27,000h−1, CO2 conversion decreased from ∼31% to 8%. However, in contrast to previously reported studies, increasing the space velocity from 7,700h−1 to 27,000h−1 also decreased MeOH selectivity (Fig. 10d). However, when the GHSV was further increased to 55,000h−1, an increase in MeOH selectivity was observed. It is worth noting that under similar reaction conditions, the yields of CO and MeOH at a reaction temperature of <300 °C decreased with an increase in GHSV to 27,000h−1 probably due to a comparatively lower CO2 conversion. The MeOH yield and selectivity, however, significantly improved when the reaction temperature was raised to 300 °C. For example, at a reaction temperature of 300 °C and an increase in GHSV from 27,000h−1 to 55,000h−1, MeOH selectivity increased from ∼30% to ∼60% (Fig. 10c). As shown in Fig. 10d, the maximum MeOH and CO yields of 0.79 g/g-cat h−1 and 0.46 g/g-cat h−1, respectively, were measured at operating conditions of T = 300 °C, GHSV=55,000 h−1, and H2/CO2 = 4. The conventionally produced catalyst C2L-I, which has a similar composition as C2L, was also examined to see if the synthesis process affected its catalytic activity. The results, which are presented in Table 2 , demonstrated that the samples made using SCS were noticeably superior than the catalysts made using the traditional impregnation method. When compared to the C2L-I catalyst made using the traditional approach, the CO2 conversion over the C2L catalyst was around twice as high. The SCS-prepared C2L catalyst displayed a greater yield of MeOH under the same reaction conditions. For instance, the MeOH yield on the C2L and C2L-I catalysts was 0.08 and 0.33 g/g-cat.h at reaction conditions of T = 275 °C, P = 85 bar, and GHSV= 7,700h−1, respectively. The significantly higher performance of the C2L nanocatalyst when compared to the C2L-I catalyst may be due to the improved metal oxide dispersion, the presence of surface defects, the presence of moderately basic sites, and the presence of surface oxygen vacancies, among other variations in physicochemical properties. In fact, it has been hypothesized that hydrogen activation for CO2 hydrogenation catalysts is a limiting step for the process' overall efficiency. Several strategies have been used to enhance the chemisorption of hydrogen and the subsequent spillover to the sites for CO2 adsorion. For example K. Lee and colleagues have reported the results of palladium incorporation into ZrO2 supported zinc-based catalysts. The incorporation of Pd enhanced the CO2 adsorption capacity and methanol production rates of the catalysts by increasing the number of surface oxygen vacancies. Additionally, the H2-activation energy of the Pd-promoted catalysts was significantly lower than that of the un-promoted catalysts, according to in situ DRIFTS and kinetic studies. This resulted in increased hydrogen spillover to the Zn-sited, which enhanced the selective CO2 hydrogenation and increased overall efficiency of the catalyst [28]. Moreover, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have been used to enhance hydrogen spillover and transport to active areas. In one of the published studies, a physical mixture of a palladium supported on CNTs and a ZnO/ZrO2 based catalyst supported achieved unusually high activity, high stability, and high methanol production [93]. Furthermore, Wang et al. compared the effects of various synthesis methods on the catalytic activity of copper-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation reactions and found that the catalyst prepared using the hydrothermal method produced a comparatively higher number of moderate basic sites, which led to higher activity and methanol production [94]. 4 Conclusions In this work, the effects of incorporation of lanthana as promoters on the activity of Cu-based catalysts were investigated. The activity of the catalyst promoted with lanthana for the methanol synthesis reaction significantly increased when compared to an unpromoted Cu-based catalyst. In a wide range of reaction conditions, the exceptionally high catalytic activity of the promoted catalyst for CO2 conversion and selectivity to MeOH was attributed to the presence of Cu-LaOx mixed oxide phases, better Cu nanoparticle dispersion, oxygen vacancies, the presence of relatively more moderate basic sites, and relatively more hydrogen spillover. The lanthana-promoted catalyst had its highest activity at an operating temperature of 300 °C, a total pressure of 85b, and a GHSV of 55,000 h−1. MeOH and CO had yields of 0.79 g/g cath and 0.55 g/g cath, respectively, while the CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity were 20% and 65%, respectively. coredata.dc:description: This study deals with the development and evaluation of lanthana promoted Cu-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The samples were prepared using solution combustion synthesis method. The study demonstrates that the incorporation of 3wt% lanthana (La2O3) into a CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 results in a catalyst with exceptionally high catalytic performance. The synthesized catalysts were thoroughly characterized by various analytical tools such as HRTEM, XRD, XPS, H2-TPR, H2-TPD and CO2-TPD. The catalysts were assessed for CO2 hydrogenation reaction in a high-pressure fixed-bed reactor. The La2O3 promoted catalyst with a composition of 0.6Cu/0.3ZnO/0.03La2O3/0.07Al2O3 was selective to methanol (60%) even at an operating temperature as high as 325 °C and an operating pressure of 85 bars. Under similar operating conditions, the 0.6Cu/0.3ZnO/0.03La2O3/0.07Al2O3 catalyst exhibited better CO2 conversion, MeOH selectivity and MeOH production as compared to unpromoted catalyst, 0.6Cu/0.3ZnO/0.1Al2O3. At reaction conditions of T = 300 °C, P = 85 bar, and GHSV=55,000h-1, the lanthana promoted catalyst showed a CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity of 20% and 65%, respectively; while the production rates of carbon monoxide and methanol were 0.55 g/g-cat h−1 and 0.79 g/g-cat h−1. The high catalytic efficiency is attributed to the formation of oxygen vacancies and/or generation of defects in the catalyst surface, smaller Cu nanoparticles with LaOx, and a comparable larger number of mild basic sites. Similar catalyst prepared by wet impregnation method performed poorly, thus highlighting the role of combustion synthesis and the effect of temperature in forming unique metal oxide phases responsible for higher catalytic performance.
